Award.AwardTitle: TILES: Trajectories of Informal Learning among Engineering Students - Theoretical and Empirical Contributions for Understanding and Measuring Impact

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to understand how learning experiences outside of formal learning environments contribute to engineers' education, and how such experiences can be meaningfully assessed and credentialed. The proposed study uses a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods that will investigate informal learning experiences at three universities.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises through the potential impact that learning how to credential such informal activities can have on opening up new avenues for the education of engineers and the STEM workforce. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by creating results and research that are useful for society by informing educational policy and practices.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increasingly, opportunities for learning are moving out of formal settings such as classrooms and also going beyond curricular based learning. Even for engineering students who are enrolled in four year degree programs out-of-classroom learning is becoming crucial to their education especially in terms of workforce readiness. The TILES project has resulted in the novel research related to engineering learning across settings with emphasis on self-directed autonomy in informal settings. The project outcomes – journal and conference papers, presentations, columns, editorials, and dissertation – help us better understand the overall terrain of how people learn engineering. The development of instruments to measure learning in informal settings – such as engineering competitions – also provides ways to measure the learning outcomes, especially professional development of learners. The findings from this work confirm the high prevalence and impact of informal learning on student development and emphasize the role played on online environments, particularly online communities, in supporting learning practices of engineering students, hobbyists, and professionals. The findings from the research also indicate that formal/informal, curricular/non-curricular kind of dichotomies are becoming irrelevant as a seamless ecology of engineering learning is emerging where multiple affordances of place-based and online environments are leveraged simultaneously by learners. Studies done as part of the project The TILES project were a large effort and in addition to supporting productive collaboration of faculty across colleges and departments, the project has support over a dozen students and a postgraduate researcher, who have gone on to academic as well as industrial jobs.
